verses.text: Then the LORD answered Job out of the whirlwind and said:
verses.comment: God's appearance in the whirlwind demonstrates his majesty and power. Storm imagery here reveals the intensity and authority of divine speech (see also Psalm 18 and Elijah's encounter).

verses.text: "Who is this that darkens counsel by words without knowledge?
verses.comment: God criticizes ignorance and calls for true wisdom, foreshadowing later biblical teaching on humility before divine mystery.

verses.text: Prepare yourself like a man; I will question you, and you shall answer me.
verses.comment: God calls Job to be courageous and accept responsibility, reminiscent of biblical figures challenged by God to rise to the occasion (cf. Job 40:7).

verses.text: "Where were you when I laid the foundations of the earth? Tell me, if you have understanding.
verses.comment: God's creative act is beyond human grasp. This highlights the Creator-creature distinction, a foundation for theological humility.

verses.text: Who determined its measurements—surely you know! Or who stretched the line upon it?
verses.comment: God uses imagery of construction, echoing wisdom traditions about divine architecture (cf. Proverbs 8:27-29).

verses.text: On what were its bases sunk, or who laid its cornerstone,
verses.comment: Cornerstone language anticipates messianic imagery later fulfilled in Christ (see Psalm 118:22, Matthew 21:42).

verses.text: when the morning stars sang together and all the sons of God shouted for joy?
verses.comment: Heavenly beings rejoiced at creation, a theme that points to sacred liturgy in both heaven and earth.

verses.text: "Or who enclosed the sea with doors, when it burst forth from the womb,
verses.comment: God describes the chaotic sea as subject to his authority, echoing creation's ordering (see Genesis 1:9-10).

verses.text: when I made the clouds its garment and thick darkness its swaddling band,
verses.comment: Clouds and darkness are metaphors for God's mysterious acts in creation and protection (cf. Psalm 18:11).

verses.text: and set limits for it and established bars and doors,
verses.comment: God's sovereignty is seen in setting boundaries, a theme common in the wisdom literature.

verses.text: and said, ‘Thus far shall you come, but no farther, and here shall your proud waves be stopped’?
verses.comment: God's command over the sea symbolizes his rule over natural forces and chaos.

verses.text: "Have you ever commanded the morning, and appointed the dawn to take its place,
verses.comment: Only God governs the cycles of day and night, underlining human dependence on divine providence.

verses.text: that it might grasp the edges of the earth and shake the wicked out of it?
verses.comment: Morning brings both judgment and renewal, a motif echoed in biblical salvation history.

verses.text: It is changed like clay under a seal, and its features stand out like those of a garment.
verses.comment: The earth’s transformation each morning shows God’s continual creative action.

verses.text: From the wicked their light is withheld, and the raised arm is broken.
verses.comment: God’s justice is manifest in limiting the power and freedom of the evil-doers.

verses.text: "Have you entered into the springs of the sea, or walked in the deep recesses of the ocean?
verses.comment: God’s knowledge surpasses human scientific exploration and discovery.

verses.text: Have the gates of death been revealed to you, or have you seen the gates of deep darkness?
verses.comment: Death and Hades are mysteries known fully only by God, later alluded to as Christ descends in victory in New Testament theology.

verses.text: Have you comprehended the width of the earth? Declare, if you know all this.
verses.comment: God’s incomprehensible wisdom contrasts with human limitation—a theme central to biblical revelation.

verses.text: "Where is the way to the dwelling of light, and where is the place of darkness,
verses.comment: Light and darkness have deep spiritual symbolism; in early Christian thought, Christ is the true light (cf. John 1:5).

verses.text: that you may take it to its territory and discern the paths to its house?
verses.comment: Light’s path is mysterious, echoing wisdom themes of God’s hidden guidance.

verses.text: Surely you know, for you were born then, and the number of your days is great!"
verses.comment: God’s rhetorical sarcasm highlights human frailty before eternal wisdom.

verses.text: "Have you entered the storehouses of the snow, or have you seen the storehouses of hail,
verses.comment: Snow and hail are instruments of God’s judgment and mercy in salvation history.

verses.text: which I have reserved for the time of trouble, for the day of battle and war?
verses.comment: God reserves the elements for sovereign purposes, including judgment and deliverance.

verses.text: By what way is the light parted, or the east wind scattered upon the earth?
verses.comment: Nature’s processes reflect God’s continuing creative involvement and governance.

verses.text: Who has cut a channel for the flood, or a path for the thunderstorm,
verses.comment: Water and storms appear as manifestations of God’s rule in creation, paralleling cosmological themes in the Psalms.

verses.text: to bring rain on a land where no human lives, on the wilderness where there is no person,
verses.comment: God’s care extends to uninhabited places, showing his gratuitous generosity beyond human awareness.

verses.text: to satisfy the desolate waste and cause the tender grass to sprout?
verses.comment: God’s providence brings life and renewal, which has spiritual meaning for renewal in times of desolation.

verses.text: Does the rain have a father? Or who has begotten the drops of dew?
verses.comment: Divine fatherhood over nature points to the mystery of creation and origin, motifs used by Jesus in teaching about God’s providence (cf. Matt 6:26-30).

verses.text: From whose womb did the ice come forth, and who has given birth to the frost of heaven?
verses.comment: Motherhood imagery of nature evokes the feminine aspect of creation, highlighting God's all-encompassing care.

verses.text: The waters become hard like stone, and the surface of the deep is frozen.
verses.comment: Even the transformation of water is in God’s hands—an echo of creation miracles (e.g., Exodus).

verses.text: "Can you bind the chains of the Pleiades, or loosen the cords of Orion?
verses.comment: God refers to constellations, showing his sovereign control over the cosmos.

verses.text: Can you lead forth the Mazzaroth in its season, or guide the Bear with its cubs?
verses.comment: ‘Mazzaroth’ refers to the zodiac or heavenly bodies, again displaying divine order in creation.

verses.text: Do you know the laws of the heavens? Can you establish their rule on the earth?
verses.comment: God is the lawgiver of the cosmos, a theme later tied to Christ as the fulfillment and sustainer of creation.

verses.text: "Can you lift up your voice to the clouds, that a flood of waters may cover you?
verses.comment: This is reminiscent of the power exercised by prophets, yet God alone commands nature.

verses.text: Can you send forth lightning that they may go and say to you, ‘Here we are’?
verses.comment: Nature’s obedience to God displays his absolute sovereignty, with overtones for later theological doctrines of obedience and service.

verses.text: Who has put wisdom in the inward parts or given understanding to the mind?
verses.comment: True wisdom originates from God, a point later central to the theology of divine grace and revelation.

verses.text: Who can count the clouds by wisdom, or tilt the water jars of the heavens,
verses.comment: God alone manages the abundance of creation, reminding us of the divine providence that underpins both natural and spiritual life.

verses.text: when the dust hardens into a mass and the clods stick together?
verses.comment: God controls the fundamental elements, tying back to his creation of humanity from dust and his ongoing oversight of creation.

verses.text: "Can you hunt the prey for the lion, or satisfy the appetite of the young lions,
verses.comment: God’s provision for animals manifests his care for all creatures, pointing to generosity and provision beyond human merit.

verses.text: when they crouch in their dens or lie in wait in their thicket?
verses.comment: Creatures’ dependence on God shows the depth of his sustaining power, echoing the spiritual dependence of believers.

verses.text: Who provides food for the raven, when its young ones cry to God and wander without food?
verses.comment: God’s care for even the raven, mentioned by Jesus as a sign of divine providence, gives hope for trust and surrender to God’s will.
